Modules and submodules

Here is reported the list of each implemented module and submodule the relative documentation

DatasetManager

Implemented dataset managers are expected to manage the dataset acquisition, the tokenization and the formatting of a partitioned dataset.

Commonly a dataset is partitioned in train, validation and test

A dataset managers is expected to have the following submodules:

dataset_reader:

a module that read the dataset from the actual dataset file

dataset_tokenizer:

a module that tokenize the acquired dataset

dataset:

a module that is a subclass of torch.utils.data.Dataset and has to prepare the tokenized dataset to be used in a torch.utils.data.Dataloader defining the batch

Entity Typing Network

Implemented entity typing networks are expected to produce a logit for each type for each input sentence.

An Entity Typing Network receives input sentences through a batch generated by the dataset submodule

To be instantiated an Entity Typing Network always needs a name, some parameters in the yaml configuration file under the key model and the number of types, given by the Dataset Manager

An Entity Typing Network is expected to have the following submodules:

encoder:

A module that encodes an input sentence starting from a tokenized version inside the batch

Commonly an encoder takes in input a tokenized sentence (a tensor of integers) and return a tensor with some representation of the input tokenized sentence

type encoder:

A module that encodes the types starting from their tokenized version (an id or a list of id) inside the batch

Commonly a type encoder takes in input a type id or a list of type ids and return a tensor with some representation of the type (or the types)

input projector:

A module that projects the encoded input in a common space, where types are placed.

The input projector is needed since the encoder has not to be aware of the type representation space (we assume an encoder encodes a sentence in a space with fixed dimension, e.g., 768 for BertBase). We think that this solution helps in building simple encoder modules

Commonly a input projector takes in input the encoded input (returned from the encoder submodule) and project it in the type representation space (defined by the type encoder)
